DataElement.preferredName: Radiation Surgery Linear Accelerator Gamma Knife Device Unit Ind-3
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no/unknown indicator that asks whether the patient can be treated with either a gamma knife or a linear accelerator-based radiosurgery system.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Radiation Surgery Linear Accelerator Gamma Knife Device Unit
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information relating to a linear accelerator or gamma knife (radiation therapy in which high-energy rays are aimed at a tumor from many angles in a single treatment session) for radiation surgery treatment.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A radiation therapy technique that delivers radiation directly to the tumor while sparing the healthy tissue. Also called radiation surgery and stereotactic external beam irradiation.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure to treat cancer cells that use high energy beams.

Property.preferredName: Linear Accelerator Gamma Knife Device Unit
Property.preferredDefinition: A machine that creates high-energy radiation to treat cancer, using electricity to form a stream of fast-moving subatomic particles.  Also called mega-voltage (MeV) linear accelerator or a linac.:Radiation therapy in which high-energy rays are aimed at a tumor from many angles in a single treatment session.:A largely self-contained device designed to be incorporated into a larger device.

Concepts.definition: A type of particle accelerator that generates ionizing radiation by colliding subatomic particles traveling at high speeds along a straight chamber. This creates high-energy radiation that may be used to treat cancer.

A treatment using gamma rays, a type of high-energy radiation that can be tightly focused on small tumors or other lesions in the head or neck, so very little normal tissue receives radiation. The gamma rays are aimed at the tumor from many different angles at once, and deliver a large dose of radiation exactly to the tumor in one treatment session. This procedure is a type of stereotactic radiosurgery. Gamma Knife therapy is not a knife and is not surgery. Gamma Knife is a registered trademark of Elekta Instruments, Inc.
A largely self-contained device designed to be incorporated into a larger device.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no/unknown.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2022.12.28 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0001837. aj

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no/unknown.

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of yes, no, or unknown.

RepresentationTerm.changeDescription: 10.2.20 TL changed WFS from RETIRED PHASED OUT to RETIRED ARCHIVED. Retired DBW 4-27-2016 per Tina Taylor approved by Dianne Reeves

ValueDomain.changeDescription: 3/12/17 jk added Standard reg status; ownership transfered from CTEP to NCI Standards with concurrence of CTEP/Brian Campbell. 3/35/2016 jk removed "indeterminate" value that was added in error. 7/7/2021wz: added ALT VM name for HOPE-CARE project.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Ability to be treated with ei
ReferenceDocuments.description: Ability to be treated with either a gamma knife or a linear accelerator-based radiosurgery system
